contract: An agreement between two or more parties creating obligations that are enforceable or otherwise recognizable at law.
affidavit: A written statement confirmed by oath or affirmation, for use as evidence in court.
jurisdiction: The official power to make legal decisions and judgments.
holder in due course: A person who has received a negotiable instrument in good faith and for value, without notice of any defect in the title of the person who negotiated it.
presumption: A legal inference as to the existence or truth of a fact not certainly known, which is drawn from the known or proved existence of some other fact.
